website_content.content: Trump signs Bibles during disaster tour of Alabama - POLITICO =============== Skip to Main Content ============================= * * * * Search WASHINGTON & POLITICS --------------------- * * * * * * * 2024 ELECTIONS -------------- * * * * * * STATE POLITICS & POLICY ----------------------- * * * * GLOBAL POLITICS & POLICY ------------------------ * * * * POLICY NEWS ----------- * * * * * * * * * * * * * * NEWSLETTERS ----------- * * * * * * * * COLUMNISTS ---------- * * * * * * * * SERIES & MORE ------------- * * * * * * * * POLITICO Live ------------- * * Follow us --------- * * * * * Trump signs Bibles during disaster tour of Alabama -------------------------------------------------- ! President Donald Trump passed wrecked homes and fallen trees en route to a Baptist church in Alabama, where he thanked volunteers and commented on the destruction after a tornado devastated the area last week. | Carolyn Kaster/AP Photo By Katie Galioto 03/08/2019 03:42 PM EST * * * * Link Copied * * * * President Donald Trump on Friday extended an unusual gesture as he sought to comfort Alabama residents devastated by a tornado outbreak last weekend — he signed Bibles. Trump offered up his autograph to first responders and survivors at a Baptist church in the eastern part of the state, after tornadoes left a path of destruction nearly a mile wide and killed 23 people last Sunday. After surveying damage from above in a helicopter ride, Trump arrived in Beauregard, Alabama, a rural community hit the hardest. Trump passed wrecked homes and fallen trees en route to the Baptist church, where he thanked volunteers and commented on the destruction. “We saw things that you wouldn’t believe,” ... [Content truncated]

Its capacity to report and fact-check claims makes it a reliable resource for identifying misinformation.

ContentScore.Relevance Justification: The evidence discusses Trump's visit to Beauregard, Alabama, after a tornado, which directly relates to clarifying the video's origin compared to the claim regarding Maui.

metatags.twitter:description: Alabamians digging through the rubble of tornado devastation welcomed Friday’s visit from President Donald Trump but braced for the threat of more severe weather in the next two days.

website_content.content: Alabamians digging through the rubble of tornado devastation welcomed Friday’s visit from President Donald Trump but braced for the threat of more severe weather in the next two days. However, the danger is not as great as it was last weekend in eastern Alabama, CNN meteorologist Monica Garrett said. See who is at risk for tornadoes this weekend Tornadoes devastated Lee County in eastern Alabama then, killing at least 23 people and injuring dozens. Ten twisters struck the state and about 37 hammered the Southeast on Sunday. Related article A tornado killed 23 people in this Alabama town. Its residents say it could have been worse “A tornado is possible,” Garrett said about this weekend. “But the bull’s-eye is more to the west.” CNN meteorologist Dave Hennen said severe weather will stretch from northern Texas into eastern Oklahoma and western Arkansas from Friday afternoon till evening. The main threat will be damaging winds and an isolated tornado. About 15 million people will be under a severe storm threat from Texas to Kentucky Saturday, said CNN meteorologist Haley Brink. Also on Saturday, the greatest threat will be over parts of the Mississippi Valley centered around Memphis, but much of the area from Texas to Kentucky could see severe weather. The threat Sunday is not expected to be as widespread, Hennen said. On Friday, Trump visited Lee County, which suffered the brunt of last weekend’s storms. He toured tornado-affected areas and met with residents and officials, including Alabama Gov. Kay Ivey. “FEMA has been told directly by me to give the A Plus treatment to the Great State of Alabama and the wonderful people who have been so devastated by the Tornadoes,” the President said in a tweet Monday. FEMA has been told directly by me to give the A Plus treatment ... [Content truncated]

metatags.article:author: Izz Scott LaMagdeleine

ClaimReview.claimReviewed: Online video showed U.S. President Donald Trump

website_content.content: The claim spread after massive fires that burned in Maui in August 2023 left more than 100 people dead at the time of this writing. ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- ### Published Aug. 17, 2023 Claim: Online video showed U.S. President Donald Trump visiting Maui in the aftermath of the August 2023 wildfires. Context The footage actually showed Trump visiting Beauregard, Alabama in 2019 after a tornado killed nearly two dozen people in the area. In August 2023, social media users shared a video clip purporting to show that former U.S. President Donald Trump had visited Maui, an island in Hawaii, in the aftermath of that left a swath of destruction and more than 100 people dead as of this writing. "The People's President, Donald J. Trump and our Beautiful First Lady Melania Trump, checking up on the people of Maui after the #MauiFires," an X (formerly known as Twitter) post on Aug. 16, 2023. According to the post, the video showed Trump and his wife, former first lady Melania Trump, walking through wreckage with a FEMA truck in the background, as well as Trump speaking to a group of people saying he had met some of the survivors and family members. > TRUMP Visits Maui Hawaii, A Real President Truly cares.???? > > — STEVE #DREAM BIG...just enjoy the moment (@stevehalilovic) In addition, we found the same claim being trumpeted on other social media platforms, like . This footage didn't show Trump visiting Maui. Instead, this was footage from when he visited Beauregard, Alabama, in 2019, after a tornado killed nearly two dozen people in the area. In the video clip, Trump is heard saying: > These are incredible people. We just met some of the survivors and family members, and what they've been through is incredible. One woman lost 10 people in ... [Content truncated]

It is widely recognized for its thorough research and impartiality, providing clear references for its conclusions. Snopes excels in fact-checking viral claims, making it an essential resource for anyone seeking to discern the truth behind dubious assertions, especially in social media contexts.

ContentScore.Newness Justification: This evidence is from August 17, 2023, which is very recent relative to the current inquiry, directly addressing the claim made about Trump visiting Maui.
ContentScore.Relevance Justification: The evidence explicitly debunks the claim about Trump's alleged visit to Maui and confirms the video's origin, making it highly relevant.

website_content.content: East Alabama residents rallied around each other amid the destruction spawned by the deadliest US tornado since 2013. One of the tornadoes that ripped through Lee County was upgraded Monday to an EF-4 after meteorologists determined it brought 170 mph winds and left a track almost a mile wide. How you can help the tornado victims The path of destruction from the EF-4 is at least 24 miles long, said Chris Darden, meteorologist in charge at the National Weather Service’s Birmingham office. The path was likely longer, because the twister crossed into Georgia. Officials there are still assessing the damage, Darden said. He estimated the track was .87 miles wide. Officials said four tornadoes were confirmed in east-central Alabama. The death toll stands at 23 people, and all of them have been identified with the exception of “six (people) that could not be physically identified by sight,” Lee County Coroner Bill Harris said. Officials are in the process of fingerprinting those individuals in hopes of identifying them, Harris said. The last tornado with such a high toll was an EF-5 storm in Moore, Oklahoma, that killed 24 people in May 2013. Three children – ages 6, 9 and 10 – are among those killed in Alabama. The youngest, Armando Hernandez, was remembered as “a precious little man that was loved by everyone,” according to his aunt. Taylor Thornton, a fourth-grade student, was described as inquisitive and a positive influence on those around her. As of noon Monday, there were no more people reported missing, the coroner said, but he said the tallies of dead and missing could rise as search teams make their way into new areas. Crews will be dealing with temperatures in the 30s on Tuesday morning. The path of destruction looks “as if someone had taken a ... [Content truncated]

website_content.content: Search, rescue and recovery efforts began at sunrise Monday following what the Lee County sheriff described as the worst disaster to hit the area in at least 50 years after at least We will be updating this story all day. **Press conference highlights** Highlights from the news conference: * Lee County Sheriff Jay Jones said dozens of people are still unaccounted for, and their addresses are still being checked. * An official with the National Weather Service announced at a press conference in Lee County that to deadly tornado that killed at least 23 people in the Beauregard area has been upgraded to an EF-4. Winds are estimated to have reached 170 mph. The officials said the NWS estimated the storm's track to be a mile wide and at least 24 miles long. * Coroner Bill Harris confirmed that at least three children have died. He said their ages were 6, 9 and 10. * Smiths Station, Alabama Mayor Fred Copeland said 24 homes were destroyed in his town, leaving 24 families homeless. **1:45 p.m.: 'In a war zone'** Volunteers at St. Ellis Full Gospel Church went out to deliver food, clothing and blankets to people in the rural community around the 150-member congregation, sometimes going on foot to do so. “It’s like you’re in a war zone,” said Nikki Reese, who does outreach for the church. “Going through those areas is devastating, because it’s places we walked in childhood.” The church offered coffee and doughnuts to first responders on Monday, and stockpiled water, clothing and diapers by the early afternoon. With roads slowly opening up, volunteers planned to make trips to get food, water and warmth to people who could face another night without any of them. Getting blankets out would be a priority. “We’re going to check on ... [Content truncated]

metatags.twitter:title: Trump Surveys Tornado Damage in Alabama, and Signs Some Bibles, Too (Published 2019)
metatags.og:title: Trump Surveys Tornado Damage in Alabama, and Signs Some Bibles, Too (Published 2019)
metatags.byl: By Alan Blinder and Elizabeth Dias
metatags.twitter:description: President Trump’s visit to Beauregard came after a tornado killed 23 people, and offered him a chance to act as consoler in chief — a role in which he has sometimes struggled.

website_content.content: Advertisement You have a preview view of this article while we are checking your access. When we have confirmed access, the full article content will load. ! President Trump departed from Joint Base Andrews on Friday, on his way to visit communities in Alabama that were devastated by a tornado outbreak.Credit...Sarah Silbiger/The New York Times * March 8, 2019 BEAUREGARD, Ala. — President Trump offered words of comfort on Friday for Alabama’s tornado survivors, scrawling his presidential signature on some of their Bibles as they moved close to him at a church that provided shelter during the storm and was now doling out emergency aid. “We saw things you wouldn’t believe,” Mr. Trump said as he stood amid the wreckage and rubble of Beauregard, the site of the nation’s deadliest tornado in six years. Mr. Trump’s travels through Alabama — in a helicopter for an aerial tour, through a debris-strewn neighborhood and later at the Baptist church that has been a hub of relief efforts — were a welcome presence in Beauregard, where at least one of the storm’s victims had flown a Trump campaign flag outside his home and where Mr. Trump captured most of the vote. A few hundred people lined the two-lane county road by Providence Baptist Church to try to glimpse Mr. Trump from the grassy shoulder or the nearby cemetery. During his stop at Providence, Mr. Trump met with relatives of the 23 storm victims, as well as volunteers and emergency workers. Dressed in his presidency’s iteration of what political strategists sometimes describe as “disaster casual” — a windbreaker, showing a fraction of an open-collar shirt, and khaki pants — he posed for pictures and signed autographs, including at least one in a 12-year-old boy’s Bible. “We couldn’t get here fast enough,” Mr. Trump said ... [Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: Alamy is a stock photo agency rather than a news source. While it provides visual content for various reporting purposes, it does not engage in news reporting or fact-checking. As such, while it offers valuable imagery, it does not contribute to the verification of news narratives or misinformation.

ContentScore.Newness Justification: The date aligns with the others from March 2019, thus it is older.
ContentScore.Relevance Justification: This is a secondary source for images rather than direct reporting, so it does not strongly aid in establishing the truthfulness of the claim.

metatags.og:description: The death toll has jumped to 23 and could go higher after at least two tornadoes hit southern Lee County Sunday afternoon, according to Lee County Sheriff Jay Jones.

metatags.twitter:description: The death toll has jumped to 23 and could go higher after at least two tornadoes hit southern Lee County Sunday afternoon, according to Lee County Sheriff Jay Jones.

website_content.content: Death toll rises after east Alabama tornadoes =============== * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * Dismiss Breaking News Alerts Bar Death toll rises after east Alabama tornadoes ============================================= ##### First tornado was at least an EF-3 and half a mile wide, according to National Weather Services ! Severe weather storm damage in Beauregard, AL((Source: WTVM Viewer)) By Morgan Carlson and WSFA 12 News Staff Updated: Mar. 3, 2019 at 11:30 PM CST LEE COUNTY, AL (WSFA) - The death toll has jumped to 23 and could go higher after at least two tornadoes hit southern Lee County Sunday afternoon, according to Lee County Sheriff Jay Jones. The sheriff said people are still reported missing, and a more organized search will be conducted in the morning. “We’ve done everything we feel like we can do this evening. The area is just very, very hazardous to put anybody in to at this point in time - debris everywhere and it’s just...just some mass damage to structures and residences in the area,” Jones said. He didn’t give any details about the locations or exact circumstances of the deaths. the victims range in age from children to older adults. Family members on the scene identified one of the victims as an 8-year-old girl. It’s unclear how many people are injured. Sunday afternoon, East Alabama ... [Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: WSFA is a regional news station based in Alabama, focusing primarily on local news. While it covers significant regional stories and sometimes national news, its scope and resources may be limited compared to larger media outlets. Still, it adheres to journalistic standards and can provide valuable local insights, although not as extensive in fact-checking efforts for national claims.

ContentScore.Newness Justification: Released in March 2019, this evidence is older but discusses tornado events in Alabama.
ContentScore.Relevance Justification: Similar to others, it contributes context but is less direct in addressing the false claim made about Trump's Maui visit.
